questions.question: His jokes fell ………………………….
questions.description: If something falls flat it fails to produce the intended result.

questions.question: When his friend was in trouble, he took up the …………………………… on his behalf.
questions.description: To take up the cudgels is to defend or support somebody.

questions.question: By endorsing that forged document, he cut his own ……………………….
questions.description: To cut your own throat is to behave in a way that will cause harm to you.

questions.question: Once she entered the show business she seemed to carry all ………………………. her.
questions.description: To carry all before one is to be completely successful.

questions.question: It is always bad manners to …………………………… over your opponent.
questions.description: To crow over is to exult loudly.

questions.question: Her beauty took my ……………………………. away.
questions.description: When something takes your breath away you are very much surprised by it.

questions.question: Parental property is the ………………………………. of contention between the brothers.
questions.description: The bone of contention is the cause of dispute.

questions.question: When I met him at the party, he cut me ……………………………
questions.description: To cut someone dead is to insult them by ignoring them deliberately.

questions.question: There is no harm in using social media, but you must draw the ………………………….. somewhere.
questions.description: To draw the line is to fix the limits.

questions.question: My wife and I do not always …………………………….
questions.description: To see eye to eye is to agree with.

questions.question: He lost the game but put a brave ……………………………… on it.
questions.description: To put a brave face on something is to accept an unpleasant experience courageously.

questions.question: He is a far …………………………… from his idealistic brother.
questions.description: To be a far cry is to be very different.

questions.question: The supervisor was fired because he had sticky ...................................
questions.description: When you have sticky fingers you are a thief.

questions.question: He really gave me a ............................................ for my money when we played poker yesterday. He almost beat me.
questions.description: To give someone a run for their money is to compete with them at their level and make it hard for them to succeed.

questions.question: Why are you being so ..........................................?  You don't even pay for your drinks.
questions.description: To be closefisted or hardfisted is to be stingy.

questions.question: Whenever I eat out with my friends, I prefer to go ....................................
questions.description: To go Dutch is to pay for your own meal.

questions.question: He had to ........................................... over a lot of money last month for violating traffic rules.
questions.description: To fork over a lot of money is to have to spend a lot of money.

questions.question: 'Do you think you could lend me some money?' 'No, I am in the ..................................... this month'.
questions.description: When you are in the red, you lose more money than you make.

questions.question: The corrupt cops receive ............................................. for ignoring certain crimes.
questions.description: To receive kickbacks is to receive bribes.

questions.question: We have been living hand to ........................................... since I lost my job.
questions.description: To live hand to mouth is to live without a lot of money.

questions.question: I don't earn much from my job as a freelance writer, but I can make ends ..........................................
questions.description: To make ends meet is to earn enough money to pay for food and bills.

questions.question: Why are you looking upset? Keep your ...................................... up.
questions.description: To keep your chin up is to stay strong.

questions.question: 'How are you doing in Singapore?' 'I'm still finding my .............................................'
questions.description: When you are finding your feet, you are adjusting to the new environment.

questions.question: I thought the interview would be difficult but it was a piece of ......................................................
questions.description: When something is a piece of cake it is easy to complete or accomplish.

questions.question: I have real trouble getting on ……………………. my landlady.
questions.description: To get on with somebody is to maintain good relation with them.

questions.question: The rich man looks down ………………………….. his poor neighbors.
questions.description: To look down upon somebody is to consider them inferior.

questions.question: The chief guest gave …………………. the prizes.
questions.description: To give away the prizes is to distribute the prizes.

questions.question: If you don’t know the meaning of a word, you should look it ………………………..
The teacher was very popular among her students and they all looked ……………………… to her.
questions.description: To look up to somebody is to have a great deal of respect for them.

questions.question: The bridge gave …………………………. under the weight of heavy traffic.
questions.description: Give way can mean collapse.

questions.question: He could not put ………………………….. with such an insult.
questions.description: To put up with insult is to tolerate it.

questions.question: She was put ……………………………. when he refused to listen to her.
questions.description: To put somebody out is to annoy them.

questions.question: You must put ………………………… something for the rainy day.
questions.description: Put by can mean save an amount to use later.

questions.question: She could not see ………………………….. his game.
questions.description: When you can see through something you can detect the true nature of it.

questions.question: The twin girls take ………………………….. their mother.
questions.description: Take after = resemble

questions.question: The manager took him …………………………… task.
questions.description: To take somebody to task is to rebuke them.
